chief.note: Commissioned as Consul General only and used the title Agent and Consul General with the acquiescence of the Department of State.
Commissioned as Consul General only and used the title Agent and Consul General with the Acquiescence of the Department of State.

Commissioned as Consul General only and used the title Agent and Consul General with the Acquiescence of the Department of State. Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Apr 18, 1854. De Leon’s immediate successor, William Sydney Thayer, was commissioned as Consul General only and used only his consular title. Thayer was commissioned Mar 20, 1861; assumed charge, Jul 1, 1861; and died at post, Apr 10, 1864.
Commissioned as Consul General only; not recommissioned when his title was changed to Agent and Consul General by Act of Congress approved Jun 20, 1864.
Commissioned as Consul General only; used the title Agent and Consul General with the acquiescence of the Department of State.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 11, 1872.
Declined appointment.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Oct 29, 1881.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Jan 20, 1886.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; died in Venice on way home.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 8, 1892.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Aug 25, 1893.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 13, 1899.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Nov 24, 1903.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 15, 1905.
Received by the Sultan on Feb 7, 1918.
Received by the Sultan on Aug 2, 1920.

ended.note: Promoted to Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary

chief.note: No record has been found of the date on which Howell was presented to the Sultan as Agent and Consul General.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Jan 15, 1934. Also accredited to Saudi Arabia; resident at Cairo.
Also accredited to Saudi Arabia and to the Government of Greece established in Egypt; resident at Cairo.

ended.note: Promoted to Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Jan 13, 1947.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Mar 2, 1949.

ended.note: Recommissioned and reaccredited after formation of the United Arab Republic

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Jan 29, 1957. Also accredited to Yemen; resident at Cairo.
Commissioned to the United Arab Republic; also accredited to Yemen and resident at Cairo.
Commissioned to the United Arab Republic; also accredited to Yemen and resident at Cairo.
Commissioned to the United Arab Republic.
Commissioned to the United Arab Republic.

Commissioned to the United Arab Republic. Proceeded to post, but did not present credentials; left post Jun 10, 1967, the United Arab Republic having severed diplomatic relations with the U.S., Jun 6, 1967. David G. Nes was serving as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim when the break in relations occurred. A U.S. Interests Section was established in the Spanish Embassy on Jun 7, 1967. Principal Officers were: Donald C. Bergus, Sep 1967-Feb 1972; Joseph N. Greene, Jr., Feb 1972-Jul 1973; and Hermann F. Eilts, Nov 1973-Feb 1974.
The Embassy in Cairo was reestablished Feb 28, 1974, with Ambassador-designate Eilts in charge pending his nomination, commissioning, and presentation of his letter of credence.
